newsitem.title: JAPAN: Greenspan not worried by Japan's bad loan problem.
newsitem.headline: Greenspan not worried by Japan's bad loan problem.

text.p: U.S. Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told a news conference in Tokyo on Tuesday that he was not worried about Japan's bad loan problem.

"I must say to you I would be terribly concerned about resolution of these difficult problems if I came here and found that the Japanese banks, the Ministry of Finance and the Bank of Japan are not fully aware of what's going on," he said.
Greenspan was referring to problems in Japan's financial system and non-performing loans held by Japanese financial institutions.
"I don't think there are reasonable expectations of concerns now that the issue has been joined," he said.
Greenspan said reforms of Japan's financial system would bring about increased competition in Japan.
"I suspect we are going to be looking forward to a major (and) increasingly important integration of the international financial system."

Greenspan said that Japan's initiatives to reform its financial institutions and revise the Bank of Japan law to increase the central bank's independence are "very specific and concrete and in my judgement a potentially effective means in dealing with those problems".
"I think the prime minister and the finance minister's initiative struck me as a very hopeful sign for the future."
Greenspan said he was "somewhat suprised" at Japan's high degree of commitment to implementing its "Big Bang" financial reform.
"I must say I was somewhat surprised...I found a much higher degree of commitment to implement these (reforms) than I had expected."
"I suspect that they will succeed."
He said there was no alternative to Tokyo as a key third financial market. "The only question is how successful it will be," he said.

"It obviously matters to the United States...and to the rest of the world...because international finance is not a zero sum gain, there is a synergetic interaction which creates benefits to all of us," he told the news conference.
Greenspan also said that he was sceptical about the concept of currency ranges.
"Until I see some evidence...that such types of ranges really do work, I would be sceptical," he said.
Referring to opinions about currency ranges held by financial analysts such as Fred Bergsten, he added:
"I'm less inclined to believe you can implement these kinds of ranges.
"The type of system we have probably is about as good as we are going to get for the time being."
Greenspan said he felt the "Big Bang" financial reform plan announced by Japan last week would contribute to the wider use of the yen as an international currency.
"I don't see how it can fail," he said, adding that "one of the basic problems in not investing in yen-based securities is the underlying structure".
